isis.stitle: SPICER 14-INCH (356 MM) AND 15 1/2-INCH (394 MM) TWO-PLATE, PULL-TYPE CLUTCH - INSTALL - 15 1/2-INCH (394 MM) CLUTCH

step1.para: Install a new pilot bearing in the flywheel. If the old bearing must be reused, clean and check it thoroughly.
Check fit of splined hubs of front and rear friction discs on the main drive gear splines of the transmission to be used. Hubs must slide freely for proper clutch release.

If the flywheel has been replaced, always check the face and pilot diameters with a dial indicator to make sure total indicator runouts are within specifications. Refer to Transmission Clutch Housing and Engine Flywheel Housing.
Insert two guide studs, 7/16" X 14NC X 5" (127 mm) long into the two upper mounting holes of the flywheel ( Figure 34). Rotate the flywheel to level the guide studs.
Insert the spline aligning tool through the release bearing sleeve ( Figure 35).

figure.caption: Figure 35. Insert Spline Aligning Tool Through Release Bearing Sleeve

step1.para: Install the rear driven disc ( Figure 36) on the tool with the side stamped "pressure plate" facing the pressure plate.
Place the intermediate plate in the clutch cover. Align the driving lugs of the plate with the slots provided ( Figure 37).

figure.caption: Figure 37. Place Intermediate Plate in Clutch Cover

note.para: 15 1/2-inch (394 mm) two-plate clutches have roll pin separators in the intermediate plate drive lugs ( Figure 37, inset). The roll pins assure equal intermediate plate separation when the clutch is released.

step1.para: Position the intermediate plate so that the pins set toward the flywheel side. The pins should be flush on the pressure plate side.

note.para: The separator pins will allow the intermediate plate to move back .025"-.030" when the clutch is released, giving a constant gap on both sides of the intermediate plate ( Figure 38).

figure.caption: Figure 38. Gap on Side of Intermediate Plate

step1.para: Install the front driven disc ( Figure 39) on the aligning tool with the side stamped "flywheel" facing the engine. Double check that driven discs are as shown ( Figure 40).

figure.caption: Figure 40. Check That Driven Discs Are As Shown

step1.para: Position the clutch over the two guide studs ( Figure 41) and slide the assembly forward until it starts in the flywheel pilot.
Start six 7/16-inch, Grade 8 mounting bolts with lockwashers and tighten finger tight.

figure.caption: Figure 41. Position Clutch Over Guide Studs

step1.para: Tap the aligning tool to make sure it is centered and seated in the pilot bearing ( Figure 42).
Remove the two guide studs and replace them with 7/16-inch bolts and lockwashers.

caution.para: If the bolts are not tightened in sequence, it can cause permanent damage and/or an out of balance condition.

step1.para: Tighten the eight bolts progressively in the sequence shown ( Figure 43). Tighten to 46 to 51 ft-lbs. (62 to 69 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 43. Tighten Bolts in Sequence Shown

step1.para: Use a 1/4-inch (6.35 mm) flat-nosed drift as shown in Figure 44. Lightly tap each roll pin separator toward the flywheel. The four 5/16-inch (7.94 mm) access holes are shown in Figure 45. The roll pins must be flush against the flywheel.

caution.para: Do not use screwdrivers, cold chisels, tapered drifts or any other sharp or tapered tools to install roll pin separators. Use of these tools will damage the separator pins and cause the clutch to malfunction.

warning.para: To avoid possible eye injury, wear safety glasses.

note.para: Check wear on fingers of clutch release yoke, cross shaft and cross shaft bushings. Replace if necessary.
